item.title: Cloud Gaming to Reach New Heights: GeForce NOW’s Blackwell RTX Upgrade Begins Next Week

review.headline_rewrite: Cloud Gaming to Reach New Heights: GeForce NOW’s Blackwell RTX Upgrade Begins Next Week
bullets: NVIDIA Blackwell RTX is coming to the cloud on Wednesday, Sept.
10 — an upgrade so big it couldn’t wait until a Thursday.
Don’t miss a special early GFN Thursday next Wednesday as GeForce NOW begins lighting up the globe with GeForce RTX 5080-class power streaming from the cloud.
With this upgrade, cloud gaming is about to level up.
NVIDIA Blackwell RTX brings GeForce RTX 5080-powered streaming to GeForce NOW, unlocking the highest resolutions and frame rates ever in the cloud.
Plus, the highly anticipated shooter Battlefield 6 is launching in the cloud in October.

item.title: Google’s Circle to Search can now translate as you scroll

review.headline_rewrite: Google’s Circle to Search can now translate as you scroll
bullets: Since its launch last year, Google has been updating Circle to Search with more functionality.
These changes included expanded AI Overviews for visual searches and one-tap actions for phone numbers, URLs, and email addresses shown on screen.
A few months ago, the tech giant made it possible to use AI Mode, its feature that lets users dig into complex topics and ask follow-up questions, when starting a search with Circle to Search.

item.title: Only 2 days left to claim your exhibitor spot at TechCrunch Disrupt 2025

review.headline_rewrite: Only 2 days left to claim your exhibitor spot at TechCrunch Disrupt 2025
bullets: We’re in the final stretch — with just two days left and only 10 tables remaining, now is the time to act if you want to shine the light on your brand at one of the most anticipated tech conferences of the year.
Disrupt is the launchpad for scaling startups — claim your exhibit table before your competitor does.

What you get with your table
Enjoy three full days of brand spotlighting in the heart of Disrupt — where investors are scouting their next deal, your target customers are ready to buy, and the tech press is searching for the next breakthrough, plus:
- A 6’ x 30″ table with linen and chairs, complete with an 11” x 14” branded tabletop sign for all-day visibility.

item.title: Six years after launch, Apple Arcade is striving for a bigger audience

review.headline_rewrite: Six years after launch, Apple Arcade is striving for a bigger audience
bullets: In 2019, Apple Arcade launched with roughly 70 premium mobile games that had no ads, no in-app purchases, and no sex or violence.
Some of the games in the initial launch period, like What the Golf?, were praised for their innovation and depth beyond what’s typically expected of mobile games.
In the six years since, Apple Arcade has grown its game offerings, and while it maintains its credo of family-friendly content, its library no longer garners the same critical praise.

Six years after launch, Apple Arcade is striving for a bigger audience
Apple has shifted focus from premium mobile titles but says it hasn’t abandoned them completely.
“Apple has a very large customer base,” said Rothman.
“There’s no narrow lane that we can operate in and satisfy the broad base of Apple users.” That broad base has led to a multifaceted strategy of game acquisitions for the service.

item.title: The quest to keep OpenAI honest

review.headline_rewrite: The quest to keep OpenAI honest
bullets: We’ve covered OpenAI on Decoder in several ways this summer, from how it’s navigating the AI talent wars to how people are starting to feel attached to ChatGPT.
Next week, we’re airing a recent conversation I had with Bret Taylor, the chairman of OpenAI’s board.
But today, I want to zoom in on the battle that’s brewing about the future of OpenAI itself.
Despite being one of the most valuable companies in the world, OpenAI is still technically a nonprofit.
And now, OpenAI is trying to shake its nonprofit structure so it can raise even more money and, eventually, go public.
There’s a lot at stake here, and not just for OpenAI.

item.title: 3 Best Robot Lawn Mowers (2025), Tested and Reviewed

review.headline_rewrite: 3 Best Robot Lawn Mowers (2025), Tested and Reviewed
bullets: - Cameras: These mowers have cameras and onboard AI for obstacle detection and avoidance.
It is also fairly quiet and has GPS tracking, but you must have Wi-Fi coverage in your backyard, or you'll need a 4G data subscription.
The object avoidance was solid, and it can be automated in the app, though it occasionally failed to start a scheduled cut for me.
After trying multiple fixes to no avail and going through customer support, I had to conclude that this model has a serious design flaw.
Robot mowers and their charging stations usually have an IP rating and can cope with rain, but you should pack up and bring your mower indoors or into the garage during the winter months.
Many robot mowers have some kind of rain sensor and will pause mowing when it gets too wet.
